titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Leonard Bacon Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:43

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of correspondence, writings, printed material and other papers that document the life and work of the poet Leonard Bacon. Correspondence is both professional and personal, and documents Bacon's writing and publishing activities as well as his personal and family relationships. Writings include drafts and proofs for many of his published works including Ulug Beg (1923), Lost Buffalo, and Other Poems (1930), The Furioso (1932), Dream and Action (1934), and Semi-Centennial (1939), as well as works translated by Bacon, such as Luis de Camões's The Lusiads (1950). Printed material includes several boxes of printed versions of Bacon's poetry and other writings, as well as pamphlets, reprints, newspaper clippings, and ephemera collected by Bacon. Other papers include three scrapbooks documenting Bacon's career from 1923 to 1946, as well as a small quantity of personal documents and photographs.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Leonard and Martha Bacon, 1955-1968. Gift of Helen H. Bacon, 1996. Other material acquired from various sources, 1967-1979. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Leonard Bacon Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Leonard Bacon Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection received preliminary processing at or near the time of acquisition. Further organization, rehousing, and description were carried out in 2011.
The collection includes material formerly classed as: Za Bacon, Uncat ZA MS Bacon, Uncat ZA File Bacon, and Uncat ZA MS 493.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Leonard Bacon (1887-1954)
bioghist.p: Leonard Bacon, American poet, literary critic, and teacher, was born in Solvay, New York on May 26, 1887. He was the son of Nathaniel Terry Bacon and Helen Hazard Bacon. He graduated in 1909 from Yale, where he studied with Chauncey Brewster Tinker and co-edited the literary magazine. Bacon taught English at the University of California, Berkeley between 1910 and 1923. Shortly after the successful publication of his first book Ulug Beg (1923), he retired from education to pursue his literary career. Bacon published several volumes of poetry, including Sunderland Capture, and Other Poems (1940) which won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry, as well as translations and an autobiography. In addition to his books, Bacon's poems were published in magazines such as The Saturday Review of Literature , The Atlantic , and The New Yorker .
Bacon married Martha Sherman Stringham on May 16, 1912, and they had three daughters. Bacon died in 1954.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, writings, printed material and other papers that document the life and work of the poet Leonard Bacon. Correspondence is both professional and personal, and documents Bacon's writing and publishing activities as well as his personal and family relationships. Writings include drafts and proofs for many of his published works including Ulug Beg (1923), Lost Buffalo, and Other Poems (1930), The Furioso (1932), Dream and Action (1934), and Semi-Centennial (1939), as well as works translated by Bacon, such as Luis de Camões's The Lusiads (1950). Printed material includes several boxes of printed versions of Bacon's poetry and other writings, as well as pamphlets, reprints, newspaper clippings, and ephemera collected by Bacon. Other papers include three scrapbooks documenting Bacon's career from 1923 to 1946, as well as a small quantity of personal documents and photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Correspondence, 1834-1962. II. Writings, 1906-1954. III. Printed Material, undated. IV. Other Papers, 1917-1951.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I consists of the personal and professional correspondence of Leonard Bacon. While correspondence is chiefly incoming, some files include original and retained copies of outgoing letters. Also included in this series is third-party family correspondence, chiefly between Leonard Bacon's parents, Nathaniel Terry Bacon and Helen Hazard Bacon, and a file containing a letter by Reverend Leonard Bacon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II includes drafts and proofs of many of Bacon's published works, including Ulug Beg (1923), Lost Buffalo, and Other Poems (1930), The Furioso (1932), Dream and Action (1934), and Semi-Centennial (1939), as well as works translated by Bacon, such as Luis de Camões's The Lusiads (1950). Also included is one box of memoranda, correspondence, and notes and drafts related to Bacon's work on a military dictionary and lexicography project. Writings also include drafts of poems, essays, book reviews, journals, and translations by Bacon, both published and unpublished.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title or in some case by author. Untitled materials are arranged by genre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III is comprised of printed versions of Leonard Bacon's writings, as well as periodicals, pamphlets, reprints, bulletins, programs, newspaper clippings and other printed ephemera collected by Bacon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV contains scrapbooks, personal papers and effects, and photographs. It also contains an original drawing by Charles Child, inscribed to Leonard Bacon.
